<item><title>SpaceX Dragon cargo capsule splashes down in Pacific Ocean</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/spacex-dragon-cargo-ship-heads-back-earth-133829779.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/zE_oMtYOLpa8_Qs2wPfH2w--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-11T195056Z_2_LYNXNPEC4A10R_RTROPTP_2_SPACE-SPACEX-STATION.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="A NASA photo shows a SpaceX Dragon capsule as it is released from the International Space Station" align="left" title="A NASA photo shows a SpaceX Dragon capsule as it is released from the International Space Station" border="0" /></a>By Irene Klotz CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (Reuters) - A SpaceX Dragon capsule splashed down in the Pacific Ocean on Wednesday carrying about 3,700 pounds (1,680 kg) of experiment results and cargo from the International Space Station, NASA said. It was the first return load from the station in a year, following a SpaceX launch accident in June 2015 that destroyed another unmanned Dragon capsule. The company’s Dragon capsules are currently the only ships that can return cargo from the station, a $100 billion research laboratory that flies about 250 miles (400 km) above Earth.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/spacex-dragon-cargo-ship-heads-back-earth-133829779.html</link><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 16:38:29 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">spacex-dragon-cargo-ship-heads-back-earth-133829779</guid><media:content url="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/zE_oMtYOLpa8_Qs2wPfH2w--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-11T195056Z_2_LYNXNPEC4A10R_RTROPTP_2_SPACE-SPACEX-STATION.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/spacex-dragon-cargo-ship-heads-back-earth-133829779.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/zE_oMtYOLpa8_Qs2wPfH2w--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-11T195056Z_2_LYNXNPEC4A10R_RTROPTP_2_SPACE-SPACEX-STATION.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="A NASA photo shows a SpaceX Dragon capsule as it is released from the International Space Station" align="left" title="A NASA photo shows a SpaceX Dragon capsule as it is released from the International Space Station" border="0" /></a>By Irene Klotz CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (Reuters) - A SpaceX Dragon capsule splashed down in the Pacific Ocean on Wednesday carrying about 3,700 pounds (1,680 kg) of experiment results and cargo from the International Space Station, NASA said. It was the first return load from the station in a year, following a SpaceX launch accident in June 2015 that destroyed another unmanned Dragon capsule. The company’s Dragon capsules are currently the only ships that can return cargo from the station, a $100 billion research laboratory that flies about 250 miles (400 km) above Earth.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>'Hyperloop' sled speeds through U.S. desert via electromagnets</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/hyperloop-sled-speeds-u-desert-via-electromagnets-001327221--finance.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/4UHil3xwgeHgNSWeyFIF9Q--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-12T003733Z_1006990002_LYNXNPEC4B01B_RTROPTP_2_CTECH-US-USA-HYPERLOOP-TEST.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="A man looks over a mock-up of a test sled following a propulsion open-air test at Hyperloop One in North Las Vegas" align="left" title="A man looks over a mock-up of a test sled following a propulsion open-air test at Hyperloop One in North Las Vegas" border="0" /></a>By Rory Carroll NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev. (Reuters) - A car-sized sled powered by electromagnets rocketed to more than 100 miles (160 kph) an hour through the Nevada desert on Wednesday in what the Los Angeles company developing the technology said was the first successful test of a futurist transit system called hyperloop. Hyperloop One is among several companies competing to bring to life a technical vision by Elon Musk, the founder of rocket maker SpaceX and electric car company Tesla Motors, who suggested sending pods holding passengers and cargo inside giant vacuum tubes between Los Angeles and San Francisco.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/hyperloop-sled-speeds-u-desert-via-electromagnets-001327221--finance.html</link><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 20:37:33 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">hyperloop-sled-speeds-u-desert-via-electromagnets-001327221--finance</guid><media:content url="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/4UHil3xwgeHgNSWeyFIF9Q--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-12T003733Z_1006990002_LYNXNPEC4B01B_RTROPTP_2_CTECH-US-USA-HYPERLOOP-TEST.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/hyperloop-sled-speeds-u-desert-via-electromagnets-001327221--finance.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/4UHil3xwgeHgNSWeyFIF9Q--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-12T003733Z_1006990002_LYNXNPEC4B01B_RTROPTP_2_CTECH-US-USA-HYPERLOOP-TEST.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="A man looks over a mock-up of a test sled following a propulsion open-air test at Hyperloop One in North Las Vegas" align="left" title="A man looks over a mock-up of a test sled following a propulsion open-air test at Hyperloop One in North Las Vegas" border="0" /></a>By Rory Carroll NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev. (Reuters) - A car-sized sled powered by electromagnets rocketed to more than 100 miles (160 kph) an hour through the Nevada desert on Wednesday in what the Los Angeles company developing the technology said was the first successful test of a futurist transit system called hyperloop. Hyperloop One is among several companies competing to bring to life a technical vision by Elon Musk, the founder of rocket maker SpaceX and electric car company Tesla Motors, who suggested sending pods holding passengers and cargo inside giant vacuum tubes between Los Angeles and San Francisco.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>A breath test for malaria</title><description>Malaria kills an estimated half a million people every year, most of those children under the age of 5 in Sub Saharan Africa, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).  “We are giving almost 300 million doses of malaria treatment every year and we don’t even know if we are giving them to the right people,” said Odom, adding that over use of antimalarials increases the risk of drug resistance.  “We want to judiciously use antimicrobial and antimalarials only on the people that really need them.</description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/breath-test-malaria-185414512.html</link><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 14:54:14 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">breath-test-malaria-185414512</guid></item><item><title>Ancient lava bubbles reveal conditions on primordial Earth</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/ancient-lava-bubbles-reveal-conditions-primordial-earth-204602969.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/mHL46eRCfQXfA2aBNb0WSw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-09T204602Z_1_LYNXNPEC481D4_RTROPTP_2_SCIENCE-BUBBLES.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="The layers on this 2.7 billion-year-old rock, a stromatolite from Western Australia, showing evidence of single-celled, photosynthetic life on the shore of a large lake" align="left" title="The layers on this 2.7 billion-year-old rock, a stromatolite from Western Australia, showing evidence of single-celled, photosynthetic life on the shore of a large lake" border="0" /></a>By Will Dunham WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Tiny bubbles that formed inside volcanic rock 2.7 billion years ago are providing big insights into the conditions on primordial Earth. Scientists said an analysis of gas bubbles trapped in ancient basalt rock that formed from ancient lava flows in western Australia showed the planet back then possessed a much thinner atmosphere, with air pressure half of what it is today. The sun is slowly brightening over time, part of a star&#039;s natural evolution.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/ancient-lava-bubbles-reveal-conditions-primordial-earth-204602969.html</link><pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 16:46:02 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">ancient-lava-bubbles-reveal-conditions-primordial-earth-204602969</guid><media:content url="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/mHL46eRCfQXfA2aBNb0WSw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-09T204602Z_1_LYNXNPEC481D4_RTROPTP_2_SCIENCE-BUBBLES.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/ancient-lava-bubbles-reveal-conditions-primordial-earth-204602969.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/mHL46eRCfQXfA2aBNb0WSw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-09T204602Z_1_LYNXNPEC481D4_RTROPTP_2_SCIENCE-BUBBLES.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="The layers on this 2.7 billion-year-old rock, a stromatolite from Western Australia, showing evidence of single-celled, photosynthetic life on the shore of a large lake" align="left" title="The layers on this 2.7 billion-year-old rock, a stromatolite from Western Australia, showing evidence of single-celled, photosynthetic life on the shore of a large lake" border="0" /></a>By Will Dunham WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Tiny bubbles that formed inside volcanic rock 2.7 billion years ago are providing big insights into the conditions on primordial Earth. Scientists said an analysis of gas bubbles trapped in ancient basalt rock that formed from ancient lava flows in western Australia showed the planet back then possessed a much thinner atmosphere, with air pressure half of what it is today. The sun is slowly brightening over time, part of a star&#039;s natural evolution.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Record 1,284 planets added to list of worlds beyond solar system</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/record-1-284-planets-added-list-worlds-beyond-212523174.html"><img src="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/ZU6t03NMQQJKOLIOkhF4kQ--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-11T152347Z_1_LYNXNPEC4A15X_RTROPTP_2_SPACE-KEPLER.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="An artist&#039;s concept depicts select planetary discoveries made to date by NASA&#039;s Kepler space telescope" align="left" title="An artist&#039;s concept depicts select planetary discoveries made to date by NASA&#039;s Kepler space telescope" border="0" /></a>By Irene Klotz CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (Reuters) - Astronomers have discovered 1,284 more planets beyond our solar system, with nine possibly in orbits suitable for surface water that could bolster the prospects of supporting life, scientists said on Tuesday. The announcement brings the total number of confirmed planets outside the solar system to 3,264. Called exoplanets, the bulk were detected by NASA’s Kepler space telescope, which searched for habitable planets like Earth.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/record-1-284-planets-added-list-worlds-beyond-212523174.html</link><pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 17:25:23 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">record-1-284-planets-added-list-worlds-beyond-212523174</guid><media:content url="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/ZU6t03NMQQJKOLIOkhF4kQ--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-11T152347Z_1_LYNXNPEC4A15X_RTROPTP_2_SPACE-KEPLER.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/record-1-284-planets-added-list-worlds-beyond-212523174.html"><img src="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/ZU6t03NMQQJKOLIOkhF4kQ--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-11T152347Z_1_LYNXNPEC4A15X_RTROPTP_2_SPACE-KEPLER.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="An artist&#039;s concept depicts select planetary discoveries made to date by NASA&#039;s Kepler space telescope" align="left" title="An artist&#039;s concept depicts select planetary discoveries made to date by NASA&#039;s Kepler space telescope" border="0" /></a>By Irene Klotz CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (Reuters) - Astronomers have discovered 1,284 more planets beyond our solar system, with nine possibly in orbits suitable for surface water that could bolster the prospects of supporting life, scientists said on Tuesday. The announcement brings the total number of confirmed planets outside the solar system to 3,264. Called exoplanets, the bulk were detected by NASA’s Kepler space telescope, which searched for habitable planets like Earth.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Memory Eraser: This Trick Helps You Forget</title><description>For example, if you wanted to forget the details of a conversation you just had,  "you could push out of your mind a song playing in the background, or thoughts related to a scene happening outside your window or something like that," said study co-author Jeremy Manning, an assistant professor of psychological and brain sciences at Dartmouth College in New Hampshire. Although the researchers did not examine the details of the strategies people in the study employed to mentally push out certain thoughts, researchers have previously suggested two main strategies that might help in this process, Manning said. "If you don't want to think of the color blue, you think of green things instead, or red," Manning told Live Science.</description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/memory-eraser-trick-helps-forget-151348419.html</link><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 11:13:48 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.livescience.com/">LiveScience.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">memory-eraser-trick-helps-forget-151348419</guid></item><item><title>Autism Risk Linked to High Folate Levels in Pregnancy</title><description>Pregnant women who get too much folic acid may be more likely to have a child with autism, a new study suggests. The researchers found that new mothers in the study who had very high levels of folate in their blood (greater than 59 nanomoles per liter) shortly after giving birth were twice as likely to have a child who developed an autism spectrum disorder (ASD)than new mothers who had normal levels (less than 59 nm/L) of this vitamin, according to the study. The findings will be presented Friday (May 13)at the 2016 International Meeting for Autism Research in Baltimore.</description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/autism-risk-linked-high-folate-levels-pregnancy-151251480.html</link><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 11:12:51 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.livescience.com/">LiveScience.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">autism-risk-linked-high-folate-levels-pregnancy-151251480</guid></item><item><title>Big Gulp: Man Swallows Cellphone, Needs Surgery</title><description>A man in Ireland swallowed an entire cellphone that became lodged in his stomach and was tricky to remove, according to a new report of the case. The 29-year-old man was a prisoner who was brought to the emergency room after he claimed to have swallowed a cellphone earlier that day. X-rays showed the cellphone was in the man's stomach.</description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/big-gulp-man-swallows-cellphone-needs-surgery-151219627.html</link><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 11:12:19 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.livescience.com/">LiveScience.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">big-gulp-man-swallows-cellphone-needs-surgery-151219627</guid></item><item><title>Spaceflight Is Entering a New Golden Age, Says Blue Origin Founder Jeff Bezos</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/spaceflight-entering-golden-age-says-blue-origin-founder-124042102.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/K4jo1GggAriqywTtQ5B4xg--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Spaceflight_Is_Entering_a_New-87087a247dd9736cb80fc38b82ed5b89" width="130" height="86" alt="Spaceflight Is Entering a New Golden Age, Says Blue Origin Founder Jeff Bezos" align="left" title="Spaceflight Is Entering a New Golden Age, Says Blue Origin Founder Jeff Bezos" border="0" /></a>Early Monday (Nov. 23), the private spaceflight company Blue Origin made a major stride in the pursuit of fully reusable rockets, when it launched an uncrewed vehicle into space and then soft-landed the rocket booster on the ground. &quot;It was one of the greatest moments of my life,&quot; said Jeff Bezos, Blue Origin&#039;s founder, speaking about the landing in a press briefing yesterday (Nov. 24). &quot;And my teammates here at Blue Origin, I could see felt the same way.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/spaceflight-entering-golden-age-says-blue-origin-founder-124042102.html</link><pubDate>Thu, 26 Nov 2015 07:40:42 -0500</pubDate><source url="http://www.space.com/">SPACE.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">spaceflight-entering-golden-age-says-blue-origin-founder-124042102</guid><media:content url="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/K4jo1GggAriqywTtQ5B4xg--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Spaceflight_Is_Entering_a_New-87087a247dd9736cb80fc38b82ed5b89" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/spaceflight-entering-golden-age-says-blue-origin-founder-124042102.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/K4jo1GggAriqywTtQ5B4xg--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Spaceflight_Is_Entering_a_New-87087a247dd9736cb80fc38b82ed5b89" width="130" height="86" alt="Spaceflight Is Entering a New Golden Age, Says Blue Origin Founder Jeff Bezos" align="left" title="Spaceflight Is Entering a New Golden Age, Says Blue Origin Founder Jeff Bezos" border="0" /></a>Early Monday (Nov. 23), the private spaceflight company Blue Origin made a major stride in the pursuit of fully reusable rockets, when it launched an uncrewed vehicle into space and then soft-landed the rocket booster on the ground. &quot;It was one of the greatest moments of my life,&quot; said Jeff Bezos, Blue Origin&#039;s founder, speaking about the landing in a press briefing yesterday (Nov. 24). &quot;And my teammates here at Blue Origin, I could see felt the same way.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Turkey and Football: How Astronauts Celebrate Thanksgiving in Space</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/turkey-football-astronauts-celebrate-thanksgiving-space-124032612.html"><img src="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/JOf6X_14S5QN7XRYuSEZEA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Turkey_and_Football_How_Astronauts-2bdaee27da24bc606b71b155859e11b3" width="130" height="86" alt="Turkey and Football: How Astronauts Celebrate Thanksgiving in Space" align="left" title="Turkey and Football: How Astronauts Celebrate Thanksgiving in Space" border="0" /></a>Thanksgiving in space will be a lot like the holiday down here on the ground — minus the gravity, of course. Like most Americans, NASA astronauts Scott Kelly and Kjell Lindgren have Thanksgiving (Nov. 26) off, and they&#039;ll spend the day aboard the International Space Station (ISS) watching football and enjoying a turkey-centric feast, agency officials said. Kelly and Lindgren gave viewers a look at that feast in a special Thanksgiving video this week, breaking out bags of smoked turkey, rehydratable corn, candied yams and potatoes au gratin.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/turkey-football-astronauts-celebrate-thanksgiving-space-124032612.html</link><pubDate>Thu, 26 Nov 2015 07:40:32 -0500</pubDate><source url="http://www.space.com/">SPACE.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">turkey-football-astronauts-celebrate-thanksgiving-space-124032612</guid><media:content url="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/JOf6X_14S5QN7XRYuSEZEA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Turkey_and_Football_How_Astronauts-2bdaee27da24bc606b71b155859e11b3" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/turkey-football-astronauts-celebrate-thanksgiving-space-124032612.html"><img src="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/JOf6X_14S5QN7XRYuSEZEA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Turkey_and_Football_How_Astronauts-2bdaee27da24bc606b71b155859e11b3" width="130" height="86" alt="Turkey and Football: How Astronauts Celebrate Thanksgiving in Space" align="left" title="Turkey and Football: How Astronauts Celebrate Thanksgiving in Space" border="0" /></a>Thanksgiving in space will be a lot like the holiday down here on the ground — minus the gravity, of course. Like most Americans, NASA astronauts Scott Kelly and Kjell Lindgren have Thanksgiving (Nov. 26) off, and they&#039;ll spend the day aboard the International Space Station (ISS) watching football and enjoying a turkey-centric feast, agency officials said. Kelly and Lindgren gave viewers a look at that feast in a special Thanksgiving video this week, breaking out bags of smoked turkey, rehydratable corn, candied yams and potatoes au gratin.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Shrinking Arctic bird suffers double hit from global warming: study</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/shrinking-arctic-bird-suffers-double-hit-global-warming-180143028.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/k9VS_8ykcCB0dfoyx0IZgA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-12T223820Z_1_LYNXNPEC4B1SI_RTROPTP_2_CLIMATECHANGE-REDKNOTS.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="A migrating red knot flies near the beach along the Delaware Bay in Fortescue" align="left" title="A migrating red knot flies near the beach along the Delaware Bay in Fortescue" border="0" /></a>By Alister Doyle OSLO (Reuters) - Red knots, a type of bird that makes one of the longest annual migrations, are shrinking because climate change in their Arctic nesting grounds makes life harder during their winters in Africa, scientists say. Snows in Arctic Russia now melt earlier in spring and many red knot chicks hatch too late for the annual peak of insect food spurred by the thaw, according to their report on Thursday, one of the first to link the impact of warming to a single species. Eighty percent of the birds born in Russia with long beaks survived to adulthood against just 40 percent of the short-beaked red knots, which end up eating roots of sea grasses in Africa that are less nutritious than shellfish, the study found.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/shrinking-arctic-bird-suffers-double-hit-global-warming-180143028.html</link><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 14:01:43 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">shrinking-arctic-bird-suffers-double-hit-global-warming-180143028</guid><media:content url="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/k9VS_8ykcCB0dfoyx0IZgA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-12T223820Z_1_LYNXNPEC4B1SI_RTROPTP_2_CLIMATECHANGE-REDKNOTS.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/shrinking-arctic-bird-suffers-double-hit-global-warming-180143028.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/k9VS_8ykcCB0dfoyx0IZgA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-12T223820Z_1_LYNXNPEC4B1SI_RTROPTP_2_CLIMATECHANGE-REDKNOTS.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="A migrating red knot flies near the beach along the Delaware Bay in Fortescue" align="left" title="A migrating red knot flies near the beach along the Delaware Bay in Fortescue" border="0" /></a>By Alister Doyle OSLO (Reuters) - Red knots, a type of bird that makes one of the longest annual migrations, are shrinking because climate change in their Arctic nesting grounds makes life harder during their winters in Africa, scientists say. Snows in Arctic Russia now melt earlier in spring and many red knot chicks hatch too late for the annual peak of insect food spurred by the thaw, according to their report on Thursday, one of the first to link the impact of warming to a single species. Eighty percent of the birds born in Russia with long beaks survived to adulthood against just 40 percent of the short-beaked red knots, which end up eating roots of sea grasses in Africa that are less nutritious than shellfish, the study found.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Are We Alone? Scientists have gotten to the root of the carrot, genetically speaking.    Researchers said on Monday they have sequenced the genome of the carrot, an increasingly important root crop worldwide, identifying genes responsible for traits including the vegetable&#039;s abundance of vitamin A, an important nutrient for vision.    The genome may point to ways to improve carrots through breeding, including increasing their nutrients and making them more productive and more resistant to disease, pest and drought, the researchers said.    The vitamin A in carrots arises from their orange pigments, known as carotenoids.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/scientists-peel-back-carrots-genetic-secrets-152707359.html</link><pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 13:32:16 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">scientists-peel-back-carrots-genetic-secrets-152707359</guid><media:content url="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/5vGCXHVhWtUWWFo.35CfCQ--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-09T152707Z_1_LYNXNPEC4810C_RTROPTP_2_SCIENCE-CARROTS.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/scientists-peel-back-carrots-genetic-secrets-152707359.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/5vGCXHVhWtUWWFo.35CfCQ--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-09T152707Z_1_LYNXNPEC4810C_RTROPTP_2_SCIENCE-CARROTS.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="Sliced carrots exhibiting a broad range of naturally occurring carotenoid pigments" align="left" title="Sliced carrots exhibiting a broad range of naturally occurring carotenoid pigments" border="0" /></a>By Will Dunham WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Scientists have gotten to the root of the carrot, genetically speaking.    Researchers said on Monday they have sequenced the genome of the carrot, an increasingly important root crop worldwide, identifying genes responsible for traits including the vegetable&#039;s abundance of vitamin A, an important nutrient for vision.    The genome may point to ways to improve carrots through breeding, including increasing their nutrients and making them more productive and more resistant to disease, pest and drought, the researchers said.    The vitamin A in carrots arises from their orange pigments, known as carotenoids.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Gorgeous New Mercury Maps Showcase Planet's Striking Features</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/gorgeous-mercury-maps-showcase-planets-striking-features-164334019.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/wXmBZOOE775csez.WCJwnQ--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Gorgeous_New_Mercury_Maps_Showcase-4aa266c1cf4dee21d517a11389b3a46f" width="130" height="86" alt="Gorgeous New Mercury Maps Showcase Planet&#039;s Striking Features" align="left" title="Gorgeous New Mercury Maps Showcase Planet&#039;s Striking Features" border="0" /></a>A stunning digital model of Mercury unveils the planet&#039;s striking landscape, while other new maps provide a closer look at the shadowed northern pole and reveal the highest and lowest points on the closest planet to the sun. Built with data from NASA&#039;s MESSENGER mission that orbited Mercury for four years, the new maps offer a bounty of scientific insight, while also delivering an incredible view of the planet. &quot;The wealth of these data, greatly enhanced by the extension of MESSENGER&#039;s primary one-year orbital mission to more than four years, has already enabled and will continue to enable exciting scientific discoveries about Mercury for decades to come,&quot; Susan Ensor, a software engineer at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) and manager of the MESSENGER Science Operations Center, said in a statement.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/gorgeous-mercury-maps-showcase-planets-striking-features-164334019.html</link><pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 12:43:34 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.space.com/">SPACE.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">gorgeous-mercury-maps-showcase-planets-striking-features-164334019</guid><media:content url="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/wXmBZOOE775csez.WCJwnQ--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Gorgeous_New_Mercury_Maps_Showcase-4aa266c1cf4dee21d517a11389b3a46f" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/gorgeous-mercury-maps-showcase-planets-striking-features-164334019.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/wXmBZOOE775csez.WCJwnQ--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Gorgeous_New_Mercury_Maps_Showcase-4aa266c1cf4dee21d517a11389b3a46f" width="130" height="86" alt="Gorgeous New Mercury Maps Showcase Planet&#039;s Striking Features" align="left" title="Gorgeous New Mercury Maps Showcase Planet&#039;s Striking Features" border="0" /></a>A stunning digital model of Mercury unveils the planet&#039;s striking landscape, while other new maps provide a closer look at the shadowed northern pole and reveal the highest and lowest points on the closest planet to the sun. Built with data from NASA&#039;s MESSENGER mission that orbited Mercury for four years, the new maps offer a bounty of scientific insight, while also delivering an incredible view of the planet. &quot;The wealth of these data, greatly enhanced by the extension of MESSENGER&#039;s primary one-year orbital mission to more than four years, has already enabled and will continue to enable exciting scientific discoveries about Mercury for decades to come,&quot; Susan Ensor, a software engineer at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) and manager of the MESSENGER Science Operations Center, said in a statement.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>The Universe Has Probably Hosted Many Alien Civilizations: Study</title><description>Many other planets throughout the universe probably hosted intelligent life long before Earth did, a new study suggests. The probability of a civilization developing on a potentially habitable alien planet would have to be less than one in 10 billion trillion — or one part in 10 to the 22nd power — for humanity to be the first technologically advanced species the cosmos has ever known, according to the study. "To me, this implies that other intelligent, technology-producing species very likely have evolved before us," said lead author Adam Frank, a professor of physics and astronomy at the University of Rochester in New York.</description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/universe-probably-hosted-many-alien-civilizations-study-131504109.html</link><pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 09:15:04 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.space.com/">SPACE.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">universe-probably-hosted-many-alien-civilizations-study-131504109</guid></item><item><title>Fearsome Dinosaur-Age 'Hammerhead' Reptile Ate … Plants?</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/fearsome-dinosaur-age-hammerhead-reptile-ate-plants-093253662.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/j24muUPOdL0GZo8BzzaNKw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/Hammerhead-like-reptile.jpg" width="130" height="86" alt="Fearsome Dinosaur-Age &#039;Hammerhead&#039; Reptile Ate … Plants?" align="left" title="Fearsome Dinosaur-Age &#039;Hammerhead&#039; Reptile Ate … Plants?" border="0" /></a>Despite its rows and rows of chisel- and needle-like teeth, a newly described prehistoric marine reptile wasn&#039;t a fearsome predator but rather an herbivorous giant that acted like a lawnmower for the sea, a new study finds. It&#039;s also the earliest herbivorous marine reptile on record by about 8 million years, they said. &quot;I haven&#039;t seen anything like it before,&quot; said study co-researcher Olivier Rieppel, the Rowe family curator of evolutionary biology at The Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/fearsome-dinosaur-age-hammerhead-reptile-ate-plants-093253662.html</link><pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 05:32:53 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.livescience.com/">LiveScience.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">fearsome-dinosaur-age-hammerhead-reptile-ate-plants-093253662</guid><media:content url="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/j24muUPOdL0GZo8BzzaNKw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/Hammerhead-like-reptile.jpg" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/fearsome-dinosaur-age-hammerhead-reptile-ate-plants-093253662.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/j24muUPOdL0GZo8BzzaNKw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/Hammerhead-like-reptile.jpg" width="130" height="86" alt="Fearsome Dinosaur-Age &#039;Hammerhead&#039; Reptile Ate … Plants?" align="left" title="Fearsome Dinosaur-Age &#039;Hammerhead&#039; Reptile Ate … Plants?" border="0" /></a>Despite its rows and rows of chisel- and needle-like teeth, a newly described prehistoric marine reptile wasn&#039;t a fearsome predator but rather an herbivorous giant that acted like a lawnmower for the sea, a new study finds. It&#039;s also the earliest herbivorous marine reptile on record by about 8 million years, they said. &quot;I haven&#039;t seen anything like it before,&quot; said study co-researcher Olivier Rieppel, the Rowe family curator of evolutionary biology at The Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>The Mercury Transit of the Sun on Monday is a Science Smorgasbord</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/mercury-transit-sun-monday-science-smorgasbord-134258095.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/m.MfyTs85uA6TodGVqJzWw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/The_Mercury_Transit_of_the-b78d8e81d8185cc68450d0b2a1b48a04" width="130" height="86" alt="The Mercury Transit of the Sun on Monday is a Science Smorgasbord" align="left" title="The Mercury Transit of the Sun on Monday is a Science Smorgasbord" border="0" /></a>Mercury&#039;s rare passage across the face of the sun on Monday, May 9, should be an exciting event for skywatchers and scientists alike. The planet&#039;s pass across Earth&#039;s nearest star may provide information about its thin atmosphere, assist in the hunt for worlds around other stars, and help NASA hone some of its instruments. As seen from Earth, Mercury appears to cross the disk of the sun — an event known as a transit — only about 13 times per century.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/mercury-transit-sun-monday-science-smorgasbord-134258095.html</link><pubDate>Sun, 08 May 2016 09:42:58 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.space.com/">SPACE.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">mercury-transit-sun-monday-science-smorgasbord-134258095</guid><media:content url="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/m.MfyTs85uA6TodGVqJzWw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/The_Mercury_Transit_of_the-b78d8e81d8185cc68450d0b2a1b48a04" type="image/png" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/mercury-transit-sun-monday-science-smorgasbord-134258095.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/m.MfyTs85uA6TodGVqJzWw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/The_Mercury_Transit_of_the-b78d8e81d8185cc68450d0b2a1b48a04" width="130" height="86" alt="The Mercury Transit of the Sun on Monday is a Science Smorgasbord" align="left" title="The Mercury Transit of the Sun on Monday is a Science Smorgasbord" border="0" /></a>Mercury&#039;s rare passage across the face of the sun on Monday, May 9, should be an exciting event for skywatchers and scientists alike. The planet&#039;s pass across Earth&#039;s nearest star may provide information about its thin atmosphere, assist in the hunt for worlds around other stars, and help NASA hone some of its instruments. As seen from Earth, Mercury appears to cross the disk of the sun — an event known as a transit — only about 13 times per century.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Mercury Transit: The History and Science of This Rare Celestial Event</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/mercury-transit-history-science-rare-celestial-event-134241063.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/mT3ac_ZnFeXcq4a_TnN9Jw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Mercury_Transit_The_History_and-819f7889eb79059f475206d8d4c93a2e" width="130" height="86" alt="Mercury Transit: The History and Science of This Rare Celestial Event" align="left" title="Mercury Transit: The History and Science of This Rare Celestial Event" border="0" /></a>The event, which astronomers call a transit of Mercury, will occur only 14 times during the 21st century. As seen from Earth, only transits of Mercury and Venus are possible, because these are the only planets that lie between Earth and the sun. Transits of Mercury and Venus hold an interesting place in astronomical history, mostly because of the slightly different times when the events occur as seen from different locations on the surface of the Earth.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/mercury-transit-history-science-rare-celestial-event-134241063.html</link><pubDate>Sun, 08 May 2016 09:42:41 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.space.com/">SPACE.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">mercury-transit-history-science-rare-celestial-event-134241063</guid><media:content url="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/mT3ac_ZnFeXcq4a_TnN9Jw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Mercury_Transit_The_History_and-819f7889eb79059f475206d8d4c93a2e" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/mercury-transit-history-science-rare-celestial-event-134241063.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/mT3ac_ZnFeXcq4a_TnN9Jw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Mercury_Transit_The_History_and-819f7889eb79059f475206d8d4c93a2e" width="130" height="86" alt="Mercury Transit: The History and Science of This Rare Celestial Event" align="left" title="Mercury Transit: The History and Science of This Rare Celestial Event" border="0" /></a>The event, which astronomers call a transit of Mercury, will occur only 14 times during the 21st century. As seen from Earth, only transits of Mercury and Venus are possible, because these are the only planets that lie between Earth and the sun. Transits of Mercury and Venus hold an interesting place in astronomical history, mostly because of the slightly different times when the events occur as seen from different locations on the surface of the Earth.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Albert Einstein's Signed Photo Up for Auction</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/albert-einsteins-signed-photo-auction-155928010.html"><img src="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/YGciWm9zdZVAoX6P2a530A--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/1.jpg" width="130" height="86" alt="Albert Einstein&#039;s Signed Photo Up for Auction" align="left" title="Albert Einstein&#039;s Signed Photo Up for Auction" border="0" /></a>Although Albert Einstein&#039;s many iconic photographs have been plastered across mugs and T-shirts for years, physics enthusiasts and art collectors may now be able to get their hands on one of the original, autographed photos that inspired the memorabilia, according to International Autograph Auctions, the British auction house handling the sale. Three years later, Einstein signed the photograph Karsh had taken, using an English version of the last sentence of his foreword to &quot;Relativity: A Richer Truth&quot; (1950), by Philipp Frank, according to the auction house statement.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/albert-einsteins-signed-photo-auction-155928010.html</link><pubDate>Sat, 07 May 2016 11:59:28 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.livescience.com/">LiveScience.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">albert-einsteins-signed-photo-auction-155928010</guid><media:content url="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/YGciWm9zdZVAoX6P2a530A--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/1.jpg" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/albert-einsteins-signed-photo-auction-155928010.html"><img src="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/YGciWm9zdZVAoX6P2a530A--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/1.jpg" width="130" height="86" alt="Albert Einstein&#039;s Signed Photo Up for Auction" align="left" title="Albert Einstein&#039;s Signed Photo Up for Auction" border="0" /></a>Although Albert Einstein&#039;s many iconic photographs have been plastered across mugs and T-shirts for years, physics enthusiasts and art collectors may now be able to get their hands on one of the original, autographed photos that inspired the memorabilia, according to International Autograph Auctions, the British auction house handling the sale. (AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein)" border="0" /></a>BEIJING (AP) — Tightening U.N. sanctions and an inability to freely access the Internet are inhibiting the work of North Korean scientists, Nobel Prize laureates who recently visited the country said Saturday.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Nailed it: scientists describe weird ancient hammerhead reptile</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/nailed-scientists-describe-weird-ancient-hammerhead-reptile-184029575.html"><img src="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/bz_AB.ufj5Iv30ErauUvQA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-06T184029Z_1_LYNXNPEC451BS_RTROPTP_2_SCIENCE-HAMMERHEAD.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="A fossil of Atopodentatus unicus is seen alongside a reconstruction showing what it would have looked like in life" align="left" title="A fossil of Atopodentatus unicus is seen alongside a reconstruction showing what it would have looked like in life" border="0" /></a>By Will Dunham WASHINGTON (Reuters) - It was a creature so outlandish that scientists say it reminds them of the fanciful beasts conjured up by Dr. Seuss. Scientists on Friday announced the discovery in southern China of new fossils of a reptile from 242 million years ago called Atopodentatus that clarify the nature of this strange crocodile-sized, plant-eating sea-dweller. When the first fossils of Atopodentatus were found in 2014, scientists thought, based on its poorly preserved skull, it had a down-turned snout resembling a flamingo&#039;s beak with a vertical, zipper-like mouth.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/nailed-scientists-describe-weird-ancient-hammerhead-reptile-184029575.html</link><pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 14:40:29 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">nailed-scientists-describe-weird-ancient-hammerhead-reptile-184029575</guid><media:content url="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/bz_AB.ufj5Iv30ErauUvQA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-06T184029Z_1_LYNXNPEC451BS_RTROPTP_2_SCIENCE-HAMMERHEAD.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/nailed-scientists-describe-weird-ancient-hammerhead-reptile-184029575.html"><img src="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/bz_AB.ufj5Iv30ErauUvQA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-06T184029Z_1_LYNXNPEC451BS_RTROPTP_2_SCIENCE-HAMMERHEAD.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="A fossil of Atopodentatus unicus is seen alongside a reconstruction showing what it would have looked like in life" align="left" title="A fossil of Atopodentatus unicus is seen alongside a reconstruction showing what it would have looked like in life" border="0" /></a>By Will Dunham WASHINGTON (Reuters) - It was a creature so outlandish that scientists say it reminds them of the fanciful beasts conjured up by Dr. Seuss. Scientists on Friday announced the discovery in southern China of new fossils of a reptile from 242 million years ago called Atopodentatus that clarify the nature of this strange crocodile-sized, plant-eating sea-dweller. When the first fossils of Atopodentatus were found in 2014, scientists thought, based on its poorly preserved skull, it had a down-turned snout resembling a flamingo&#039;s beak with a vertical, zipper-like mouth.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Brazil scientists seek to unravel mystery of Zika twins</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/brazil-scientists-seek-unravel-mystery-zika-twins-174532348--spt.html"><img src="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/d6mNEq_47J40xUrZGIKUbQ--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-06T190526Z_1_LYNXNPEC451D6_RTROPTP_2_HEALTH-ZIKA-TWINS.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="The Wider Image: Twins - one with microcephaly" align="left" title="The Wider Image: Twins - one with microcephaly" border="0" /></a>By Nacho Doce and Pablo Garcia SAO PAULO (Reuters) - Scientists struggling to unravel the mysteries of a Zika epidemic in Brazil hope they can learn from cases of women giving birth to twins in which only one child is afflicted by the microcephaly birth defect associated with the virus. Jaqueline Jessica Silva de Oliveira hoped doctors were wrong when a routine ultrasound showed that one of her unborn twins would be born with the condition, marked by stunted head size and developmental issues.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/brazil-scientists-seek-unravel-mystery-zika-twins-174532348--spt.html</link><pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 13:45:32 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">brazil-scientists-seek-unravel-mystery-zika-twins-174532348--spt</guid><media:content url="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/d6mNEq_47J40xUrZGIKUbQ--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-06T190526Z_1_LYNXNPEC451D6_RTROPTP_2_HEALTH-ZIKA-TWINS.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/brazil-scientists-seek-unravel-mystery-zika-twins-174532348--spt.html"><img src="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/d6mNEq_47J40xUrZGIKUbQ--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-06T190526Z_1_LYNXNPEC451D6_RTROPTP_2_HEALTH-ZIKA-TWINS.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="The Wider Image: Twins - one with microcephaly" align="left" title="The Wider Image: Twins - one with microcephaly" border="0" /></a>By Nacho Doce and Pablo Garcia SAO PAULO (Reuters) - Scientists struggling to unravel the mysteries of a Zika epidemic in Brazil hope they can learn from cases of women giving birth to twins in which only one child is afflicted by the microcephaly birth defect associated with the virus. Jaqueline Jessica Silva de Oliveira hoped doctors were wrong when a routine ultrasound showed that one of her unborn twins would be born with the condition, marked by stunted head size and developmental issues.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Governments should study worst-case global warming scenarios, former U.N. official says</title><description>By Sebastien Malo PISCATAWAY, N.J. (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - A United Nations panel of scientists seeking ways for nations to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius should not dissuade governments from concentrating on bleaker scenarios of higher temperatures as well, its former chief said on Wednesday. Nations should be considering the potential impact of temperature rises of much as 4 degrees Celsius (7.2 Fahrenheit), said Robert Watson, former head of the U.N. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. The U.N. panel was assigned to find ways to limit global warming to 1.5C (2.7F) after a 195-nation climate change summit in Paris in December.</description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/governments-study-worst-case-global-warming-scenarios-former-233631958.html</link><pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 19:36:31 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">governments-study-worst-case-global-warming-scenarios-former-233631958</guid></item><item><title>For first time, scientists grow two-week-old human embryos in lab</title><description>By Kate Kelland LONDON(Reuters) - Scientists have for the first time grown human embryos outside of the mother for almost two full weeks into development, giving unique insight into what they say is the most mysterious stage of early human life. Scientists had previously only been able to study human embryos as a culture in a lab dish until the seventh day of development when they had to implant them into the mother's uterus to survive and develop further. "This it the most enigmatic and mysterious stage of human development," said Magdalena Zernicka-Goetz, a University of Cambridge professor who co-led the work.</description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/first-time-scientists-grow-two-week-old-human-171211071.html</link><pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 13:12:11 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">first-time-scientists-grow-two-week-old-human-171211071</guid></item><item><title>Land titles for farmers help cut Brazil's forest loss: scientist</title><description>By Chris Arsenault RIO DE JANEIRO (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Brazil should speed up its program to grant small farmers formal land ownership to slow down the rate of logging and deforestation, a leading scientist said. Farmers on small holdings are responsible for about 30 percent of the logging and destruction of Brazil's vast forests, up from about 23 percent 10 years ago, said Daniel Nepstad, executive director of the California-based Earth Innovation Institute. "A lack of clear land title pushes small farmers to opt for cattle (rearing) instead of more intensive (food) production" said Nepstad, a specialist with 30 years of experience tracking Amazon deforestation told the Thomson Reuters Foundation.</description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/land-titles-farmers-help-cut-brazils-forest-loss-115936984.html</link><pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 07:59:36 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">land-titles-farmers-help-cut-brazils-forest-loss-115936984</guid></item><item><title>Scientists win $3 million for detecting Einstein's waves</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/scientists-win-3-mln-detecting-einsteins-waves-111749835.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/lq9n2CN5J0d99aIL.yLX6g--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-03T111749Z_1_LYNXNPEC420G2_RTROPTP_2_SPACE-GRAVITYWAVES-PRIZE.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="File photo of Dr. Thorne of Caltech listening during news conference on detection of gravitational waves, in Washington" align="left" title="File photo of Dr. Thorne of Caltech listening during news conference on detection of gravitational waves, in Washington" border="0" /></a>By Joseph Ax NEW YORK (Reuters) - Researchers who helped detect gravitational waves for the first time, confirming part of Albert Einstein&#039;s theory in a landmark moment in scientific history, will share a $3 million Special Breakthrough Prize, according to the prize&#039;s selection committee. The Breakthrough Prizes for scientific achievements were created by Russian billionaire Yuri Milner along with several technology pioneers, including Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg and Google co-founder Sergey Brin. In February, a team from the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) announced a pair of giant laser detectors had measured the tiny ripples in space and time first theorized by Einstein a century ago, capping a decades-long quest.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/scientists-win-3-mln-detecting-einsteins-waves-111749835.html</link><pubDate>Tue, 03 May 2016 08:19:11 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">scientists-win-3-mln-detecting-einsteins-waves-111749835</guid><media:content url="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/lq9n2CN5J0d99aIL.yLX6g--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-03T111749Z_1_LYNXNPEC420G2_RTROPTP_2_SPACE-GRAVITYWAVES-PRIZE.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/scientists-win-3-mln-detecting-einsteins-waves-111749835.html"><img src="http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/lq9n2CN5J0d99aIL.yLX6g--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-03T111749Z_1_LYNXNPEC420G2_RTROPTP_2_SPACE-GRAVITYWAVES-PRIZE.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="File photo of Dr. Thorne of Caltech listening during news conference on detection of gravitational waves, in Washington" align="left" title="File photo of Dr. Thorne of Caltech listening during news conference on detection of gravitational waves, in Washington" border="0" /></a>By Joseph Ax NEW YORK (Reuters) - Researchers who helped detect gravitational waves for the first time, confirming part of Albert Einstein&#039;s theory in a landmark moment in scientific history, will share a $3 million Special Breakthrough Prize, according to the prize&#039;s selection committee. The Breakthrough Prizes for scientific achievements were created by Russian billionaire Yuri Milner along with several technology pioneers, including Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg and Google co-founder Sergey Brin. In February, a team from the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) announced a pair of giant laser detectors had measured the tiny ripples in space and time first theorized by Einstein a century ago, capping a decades-long quest.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Science Explains Why Your Mom Calls You by Your Brother's Name</title><description>Such "misnamings," or when a person calls someone else by the wrong name, occur frequently, according to the study. When people call someone by the wrong name, they tend to call that person by the name of someone in the same social group, the researchers found.</description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/science-explains-why-mom-calls-brothers-name-144239944.html</link><pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2016 10:42:39 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.livescience.com/">LiveScience.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">science-explains-why-mom-calls-brothers-name-144239944</guid></item><item><title>Pop went the weasel and down went the Large Hadron Collider</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/pop-went-weasel-down-went-large-hadron-collider-162842566.html"><img src="http://l2.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/N93f_oJxVQyx2TWi2NIjyw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/ap_webfeeds/8496b074bd8f7915970f6a70670076e5.jpg" width="130" height="86" alt="FILE - A May 31, 2007 file photo shows a view of the Large Hadron Collider in its tunnel at the European Particle Physics Laboratory, CERN, near Geneva, Switzerland. Sleep Discovery Surprises Scientists</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/australian-dragons-dream-sleep-discovery-surprises-scientists-111818386.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/QBdXuziU2QOXxV.yi_aI.A--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/sleeping-australian-dragon.jpg1461870620" width="130" height="86" alt="Do Australian Dragons Dream? Sleep Discovery Surprises Scientists" align="left" title="Do Australian Dragons Dream? Sleep Discovery Surprises Scientists" border="0" /></a>Maybe, according to new research that finds rapid eye movement (REM) and slow-wave sleep in a lizard, the Australian dragon, for the first time. REM sleep is characterized by brain waves that look similar to waking brain activity. In mammals, the large muscles of the body are immobile, but the eyes twitch randomly during REM sleep.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/australian-dragons-dream-sleep-discovery-surprises-scientists-111818386.html</link><pubDate>Fri, 29 Apr 2016 07:18:18 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.livescience.com/">LiveScience.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">australian-dragons-dream-sleep-discovery-surprises-scientists-111818386</guid><media:content url="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/QBdXuziU2QOXxV.yi_aI.A--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/sleeping-australian-dragon.jpg1461870620" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/australian-dragons-dream-sleep-discovery-surprises-scientists-111818386.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/QBdXuziU2QOXxV.yi_aI.A--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/sleeping-australian-dragon.jpg1461870620" width="130" height="86" alt="Do Australian Dragons Dream? Sleep Discovery Surprises Scientists" align="left" title="Do Australian Dragons Dream? Sleep Discovery Surprises Scientists" border="0" /></a>Maybe, according to new research that finds rapid eye movement (REM) and slow-wave sleep in a lizard, the Australian dragon, for the first time. REM sleep is characterized by brain waves that look similar to waking brain activity. In mammals, the large muscles of the body are immobile, but the eyes twitch randomly during REM sleep.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Scientists Find New Way to Tan or Lighten Skin</title><description>Scientists have uncovered how human skin cells control pigmentation — a discovery that could lead to safer ways to tan or lighten the skin. Researchers found that skin color can be regulated by estrogen and progesterone, two of the main female sex hormones. Although this much was known to a limited degree, the new research revealed two cellular receptors that appear to control this process in skin cells called melanocytes.</description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/scientists-way-tan-lighten-skin-145527276.html</link><pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2016 10:55:27 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.livescience.com/">LiveScience.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">scientists-way-tan-lighten-skin-145527276</guid></item><item><title>Half Australia's Great Barrier Reef northern coral 'dead or dying': scientists</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/half-australias-great-barrier-reef-northern-coral-dead-071002369--finance.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/9jXVwsCanFtrqtpgdeNjcA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-04-20T061237Z_1_LYNXNPEC3J0BO_RTROPTP_2_AUSTRALIA-ENVIRONMENT-GREATBARRIERREEF.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="A tourist boat floats above an area called the &#039;Coral Gardens&#039; located off Lady Elliot Island and north-east from the town of Bundaberg in Queensland, Australia" align="left" title="A tourist boat floats above an area called the &#039;Coral Gardens&#039; located off Lady Elliot Island and north-east from the town of Bundaberg in Queensland, Australia" border="0" /></a>(This April 20 story has been corrected in headline and first paragraph to show that 50 percent of northern coral is dead or dying, not entire reef) By Colin Packham SYDNEY (Reuters) - Australian scientists said on Wednesday that just seven percent of the Great Barrier Reef, which attracts around A$5 billion ($3.90 billion) in tourism every year, has been untouched by mass bleaching that is likely to destroy half of the northern coral. Although the impact has been exacerbated by one of the strongest El Nino weather systems in nearly 20 years, scientists believe climate change is the underlying cause. In the northern Great Barrier Reef, it&#039;s like 10 cyclones have come ashore all at once,&quot; said Professor Terry Hughes, conveyor of the National Coral Bleaching Taskforce, which conducted aerial surveys of the World Heritage site.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/half-australias-great-barrier-reef-northern-coral-dead-071002369--finance.html</link><pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2016 03:37:14 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">half-australias-great-barrier-reef-northern-coral-dead-071002369--finance</guid><media:content url="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/9jXVwsCanFtrqtpgdeNjcA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-04-20T061237Z_1_LYNXNPEC3J0BO_RTROPTP_2_AUSTRALIA-ENVIRONMENT-GREATBARRIERREEF.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/half-australias-great-barrier-reef-northern-coral-dead-071002369--finance.html"><img src="http://l1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/9jXVwsCanFtrqtpgdeNjcA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-04-20T061237Z_1_LYNXNPEC3J0BO_RTROPTP_2_AUSTRALIA-ENVIRONMENT-GREATBARRIERREEF.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="A tourist boat floats above an area called the &#039;Coral Gardens&#039;
