(AP Photo/Tyler Bell, File)" border="0" /></a>Brine spills from oil development in western North Dakota are releasing toxins into soils and waterways, sometimes at levels exceeding federal water quality standards, scientists reported Wednesday.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Mysterious 'Haloes' on Pluto Puzzle Scientists</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/mysterious-haloes-pluto-puzzle-scientists-195248483.html"><img src="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/SihimewwPAxeT4NmCFogtA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Mysterious_Haloes_on_Pluto_Puzzle-7bf63f2e47cdce99b3d0f57ad260be48" width="130" height="86" alt="Mysterious &#039;Haloes&#039; on Pluto Puzzle Scientists" align="left" title="Mysterious &#039;Haloes&#039; on Pluto Puzzle Scientists" border="0" /></a>The discovery of strange halo-like craters on Pluto has raised a new mystery about how the odd scars formed on the icy world. Pluto&#039;s &quot;halo&quot; craters are clearly visible in a new image from NASA&#039;s New Horizons spacecraft, which made the first-ever flyby of the dwarf planet in July 2015. In the image, a black-and-white view reveals dozens of ringed craters (NASA describes these formations as &quot;haloed&quot;) strewn across the dark landscape of Vega Terra, a region in the far western reaches of the hemisphere photographed by New Horizons during its flyby.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/mysterious-haloes-pluto-puzzle-scientists-195248483.html</link><pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2016 15:52:48 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.space.com/">SPACE.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">mysterious-haloes-pluto-puzzle-scientists-195248483</guid><media:content url="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/SihimewwPAxeT4NmCFogtA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Mysterious_Haloes_on_Pluto_Puzzle-7bf63f2e47cdce99b3d0f57ad260be48" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/mysterious-haloes-pluto-puzzle-scientists-195248483.html"><img src="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/SihimewwPAxeT4NmCFogtA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/SPACE.com/Mysterious_Haloes_on_Pluto_Puzzle-7bf63f2e47cdce99b3d0f57ad260be48" width="130" height="86" alt="Mysterious &#039;Haloes&#039; on Pluto Puzzle Scientists" align="left" title="Mysterious &#039;Haloes&#039; on Pluto Puzzle Scientists" border="0" /></a>The discovery of strange halo-like craters on Pluto has raised a new mystery about how the odd scars formed on the icy world. Pluto&#039;s &quot;halo&quot; craters are clearly visible in a new image from NASA&#039;s New Horizons spacecraft, which made the first-ever flyby of the dwarf planet in July 2015. In the image, a black-and-white view reveals dozens of ringed craters (NASA describes these formations as &quot;haloed&quot;) strewn across the dark landscape of Vega Terra, a region in the far western reaches of the hemisphere photographed by New Horizons during its flyby.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Mars Comes to Earth: Scientists 'Visit' Red Planet with Augmented Reality</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/mars-comes-earth-scientists-visit-red-planet-augmented-150634289.html"><img src="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/NJfI2jl7fdvedzECixOeMg--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/augmented-reality-mars.jpeg1461641826" width="130" height="86" alt="Mars Comes to Earth: Scientists &#039;Visit&#039; Red Planet with Augmented Reality" align="left" title="Mars Comes to Earth: Scientists &#039;Visit&#039; Red Planet with Augmented Reality" border="0" /></a>NASA is aiming to send astronauts to Mars sometime in the 2030s, but a new technology could help scientists explore the surface of the Red Planet — from its sprawling craters to its enormous volcanoes — from right here on Earth. Researchers at NASA&#039;s Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) in Pasadena, California, partnered with Microsoft to develop software that uses the tech giant&#039;s HoloLens headsets to allow scientists to virtually explore and conduct scientific research on Mars. The HoloLens is an augmented reality platform that &quot;allows us to overlay imagery on top of the world and integrate it into that world as I&#039;m looking at it,&quot; Tony Valderrama, a software engineer at JPL, said Sunday (April 24) in a demonstration of the technology here at the Smithsonian magazine&#039;s &quot;Future Is Here&quot; festival.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/mars-comes-earth-scientists-visit-red-planet-augmented-150634289.html</link><pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2016 11:06:34 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.livescience.com/">LiveScience.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">mars-comes-earth-scientists-visit-red-planet-augmented-150634289</guid><media:content url="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/NJfI2jl7fdvedzECixOeMg--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/augmented-reality-mars.jpeg1461641826" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/mars-comes-earth-scientists-visit-red-planet-augmented-150634289.html"><img src="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/NJfI2jl7fdvedzECixOeMg--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/augmented-reality-mars.jpeg1461641826" width="130" height="86" alt="Mars Comes to Earth: Scientists &#039;Visit&#039; Red Planet with Augmented Reality" align="left" title="Mars Comes to Earth: Scientists &#039;Visit&#039; Red Planet with Augmented Reality" border="0" /></a>NASA is aiming to send astronauts to Mars sometime in the 2030s, but a new technology could help scientists explore the surface of the Red Planet — from its sprawling craters to its enormous volcanoes — from right here on Earth. Researchers at NASA&#039;s Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) in Pasadena, California, partnered with Microsoft to develop software that uses the tech giant&#039;s HoloLens headsets to allow scientists to virtually explore and conduct scientific research on Mars. The HoloLens is an augmented reality platform that &quot;allows us to overlay imagery on top of the world and integrate it into that world as I&#039;m looking at it,&quot; Tony Valderrama, a software engineer at JPL, said Sunday (April 24) in a demonstration of the technology here at the Smithsonian magazine&#039;s &quot;Future Is Here&quot; festival.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Researchers use light to battle cancer</title><description>By Ben Gruber BOSTON (Reuters) - In an intriguing approach to the fight against cancer, researchers for the first time have used light to prevent and reverse tumors using a technique called optogenetics to manipulate electrical signaling in cells. Scientists at Tufts University performed optogenetics experiments on frogs, often used in basic research into cancer because of the biological similarities in their tumors to those in mammals, to test whether this method already used in brain and nervous system research could be applied to cancer. "We call this whole research program cracking the bioelectric code," said biologist Michael Levin, who heads the Tufts Center for Regenerative and Developmental Biology.</description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/researchers-light-battle-cancer-160946114.html</link><pubDate>Tue, 26 Apr 2016 12:09:46 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">researchers-light-battle-cancer-160946114</guid></item><item><title>Lap Dinos? Gigantic Sauropods Started Out Chihuahua-Size</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/lap-dinos-gigantic-sauropods-started-chihuahua-size-132749602.html"><img src="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/vrU3AmTcWUzSkURpYt62YA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cHhvZmY9NTA7cHlvZmY9MDtxPTc1O3c9MTMw/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/Baby-Rapeto.jpg1461261999" width="130" height="86" alt="Lap Dinos? Gigantic Sauropods Started Out Chihuahua-Size" align="left" title="Lap Dinos? Gigantic Sauropods Started Out Chihuahua-Size" border="0" /></a>Now, the discovery of the animal&#039;s fossilized bones suggests that the family of ginormous dinosaurs that this titanosaur belonged to started out small — each about the size of a Chihuahua — and were precocial, a new study finds. &quot;Baby Rapetosaurus gives us our first in-depth look at a sauropod within just a few weeks of hatching,&quot; said study lead researcher Kristina Curry Rogers, an associate professor of biology and geology at Macalester College in Minnesota. &quot;That&#039;s where I found them several years ago, when I was searching for bones of ancient crocodiles and turtles,&quot; Curry Rogers told Live Science in an email.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/lap-dinos-gigantic-sauropods-started-chihuahua-size-132749602.html</link><pubDate>Mon, 25 Apr 2016 09:27:49 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.livescience.com/">LiveScience.com</source><guid isPermaLink="false">lap-dinos-gigantic-sauropods-started-chihuahua-size-132749602</guid><media:content url="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/vrU3AmTcWUzSkURpYt62YA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cHhvZmY9NTA7cHlvZmY9MDtxPTc1O3c9MTMw/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/Baby-Rapeto.jpg1461261999" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/lap-dinos-gigantic-sauropods-started-chihuahua-size-132749602.html"><img src="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/vrU3AmTcWUzSkURpYt62YA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cHhvZmY9NTA7cHlvZmY9MDtxPTc1O3c9MTMw/http://media.zenfs.com/en_US/News/LiveScience.com/Baby-Rapeto.jpg1461261999" width="130" height="86" alt="Lap Dinos? Gigantic Sauropods Started Out Chihuahua-Size" align="left" title="Lap Dinos? Gigantic Sauropods Started Out Chihuahua-Size" border="0" /></a>Now, the discovery of the animal&#039;s fossilized bones suggests that the family of ginormous dinosaurs that this titanosaur belonged to started out small — each about the size of a Chihuahua — and were precocial, a new study finds. &quot;Baby Rapetosaurus gives us our first in-depth look at a sauropod within just a few weeks of hatching,&quot; said study lead researcher Kristina Curry Rogers, an associate professor of biology and geology at Macalester College in Minnesota. &quot;That&#039;s where I found them several years ago, when I was searching for bones of ancient crocodiles and turtles,&quot; Curry Rogers told Live Science in an email.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Robot monk blends science and Buddhism at Chinese temple</title><description><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/robot-monk-blends-science-buddhism-chinese-temple-022046666.html"><img src="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/fyGGYNWpj6tCLOEF49Jwaw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-04-22T091715Z_2_LYNXNPEC3L056_RTROPTP_2_CHINA-RELIGION-ROBOT.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="Master Xianfan looks at robot monk Xian&#039;er as he demonstrates the robot&#039;s conversation function during a photo opportunity in Longquan Buddhist temple on the outskirts of Beijing" align="left" title="Master Xianfan looks at robot monk Xian&#039;er as he demonstrates the robot&#039;s conversation function during a photo opportunity in Longquan Buddhist temple on the outskirts of Beijing" border="0" /></a>By Joseph Campbell BEIJING (Reuters) - A Buddhist temple on the outskirts of Beijing has decided to ditch traditional ways and use technology to attract followers. Longquan temple says it has developed a robot monk that can chant Buddhist mantras, move via voice command, and hold a simple conversation. Named Xian&#039;er, the 2-foot tall robot resembles a cartoon-like novice monk in yellow robes with a shaven head, holding a touch screen on his chest.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>http://news.yahoo.com/robot-monk-blends-science-buddhism-chinese-temple-022046666.html</link><pubDate>Fri, 22 Apr 2016 16:34:21 -0400</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">robot-monk-blends-science-buddhism-chinese-temple-022046666</guid><media:content url="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/fyGGYNWpj6tCLOEF49Jwaw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-04-22T091715Z_2_LYNXNPEC3L056_RTROPTP_2_CHINA-RELIGION-ROBOT.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="http://news.yahoo.com/robot-monk-blends-science-buddhism-chinese-temple-022046666.html"><img src="http://l3.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/fyGGYNWpj6tCLOEF49Jwaw--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-04-22T091715Z_2_LYNXNPEC3L056_RTROPTP_2_CHINA-RELIGION-ROBOT.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="Master Xianfan looks at robot monk Xian&#039;er as he demonstrates the robot&#039;s conversation function during a photo opportunity in Longquan Buddhist temple on the outskirts of Beijing" align="left" title="Master Xianfan looks at robot monk Xian&#039;er as he demonstrates the robot&#039;s conversation function during a photo opportunity in Longquan Buddhist temple on the outskirts of Beijing" border="0" /></a>By Joseph Campbell BEIJING (Reuters) - A Buddhist temple on the outskirts of Beijing has decided to ditch traditional ways and use technology to attract followers. Longquan temple says it has developed a robot monk that can chant Buddhist mantras, move via voice command, and hold a simple conversation. Named Xian&#039;er, the 2-foot tall robot resembles a cartoon-like novice monk in yellow robes with a shaven head, holding a touch screen on his chest.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item></channel>
